name: Action API
description: The Action API allows an action extension to modally present its corresponding modal target.

ActionApiContent.name: ActionApiContent

members.name: presentModal
members.description:
Presents the `action-overlay.render` extension target on top of present view.

For example: if we are calling presentModal() from pos.purchase.post.action.menu-item.render, it should present pos.purchase.post.action.render.

examples.description: Examples of using the Action API.

codeblock.title: Present a modal from post purchase.

TS

codeblock.title: Present a modal from smart grid.

name: Cart API
description: The Cart API enables UI Extensions to manage and interact with POS cart contents, such as discounts, line items, and customer details. It provides a comprehensive set of functions for adding and removing items, alongside a subscribable object that keeps the UI Extension updated with real-time changes to the cart.

CartApiContent.name: CartApiContent

members.name: addAddress
members.description: Add an address to the customer (Customer must be present)

members.name: addCartCodeDiscount
members.description: Add a code discount to the cart

members.name: addCartProperties
members.description: Adds custom properties to the cart

members.name: addCustomSale
members.description: Add a custom sale to the cart

members.name: addLineItem
members.description: Add a line item by variant ID to the cart

members.name: addLineItemProperties
members.description: Adds custom properties to the specified line item

members.name: applyCartDiscount
members.value: (type: CartDiscountType, title: string, amount?: string) => Promise<void>
members.description: Apply a cart level discount

members.name: bulkAddLineItemProperties
members.description: Adds custom properties to multiple line items at the same time.

members.name: bulkSetLineItemDiscounts
members.description: Set line item discounts to multiple line items at the same time.

members.name: clearCart
members.description: Clear the cart

members.name: deleteAddress
members.description: Delete an address from the customer (Customer must be present)

members.name: removeAllDiscounts
members.description: Remove all cart and line item discounts

members.name: removeCartDiscount
members.description: Remove the cart discount

members.name: removeCartProperties
members.description: Removes the specified cart properties

members.name: removeCustomer
members.description: Remove the current customer from the cart

members.name: removeLineItem
members.description: Remove the line item at this uuid from the cart

members.name: removeLineItemDiscount
members.description: Remove all discounts from a line item

members.name: removeLineItemProperties
members.description: Removes the specified line item properties

members.name: setAttributedStaff
members.description: Sets an attributed staff to all line items in the cart.

members.name: setAttributedStaffToLineItem
members.description: Sets an attributed staff to a specific line items in the cart.

members.name: setCustomer
members.description: Set the customer in the cart

members.name: setLineItemDiscount
members.value: (uuid: string, type: LineItemDiscountType, title: string, amount: string) => Promise<void>
members.description: Add a discount on a line item to the cart

members.name: subscribable
members.description: Provides a subscription to POS cart changes. Provides an initial value and a callback to subscribe to value changes. Currently supports only one subscription. You can utilize `makeStatefulSubscribable` on a `RemoteSubscribable` to implement multiple subscriptions. Using `makeStatefulSubscribable` or the corresponding hooks counts as a subscription.

members.name: updateDefaultAddress
members.description: Update the default address for the customer (Customer must be present)

name: ProductSearch API
description: The ProductSearch API gives extensions access to the native product search and fetching functionality of Shopify POS. The interface provides numerous functions to search for products by query, or to fetch the details of one or more products or product variants.

ProductSearchApiContent.name: ProductSearchApiContent

members.name: fetchPaginatedProductVariantsWithProductId
members.description: Fetches a page of product variants associated with a product.

members.name: fetchProductsWithIds
members.description: Fetches multiple products' details.

members.name: fetchProductVariantsWithIds
members.description: Fetches multiple product variants' details.

members.name: fetchProductVariantsWithProductId
members.description: Fetches all product variants associated with a product.

members.name: fetchProductVariantWithId
members.description: Fetches a single product variant's details.

members.name: fetchProductWithId
members.description: Fetches a single product's details.

members.name: searchProducts
members.description: Search for products on the POS device.

PaginationParams.name: PaginationParams

members.name: afterCursor
members.description: Specifies the page cursor. Items after this cursor will be returned.

members.name: first
members.description: Specifies the number of results to be returned in this page. The maximum number of items that will be returned is 50.

PaginatedResult.name: PaginatedResult
PaginatedResult.description: Contains a page of fetched results.

members.name: hasNextPage
members.description: Whether or not there is another page of results that can be fetched.

members.name: items
members.description: The items returned from the fetch.

members.name: lastCursor
members.description: The cursor of the last item. This can be used to fetch more results. The format of this cursor may look different depending on if POS is fetching results from the remote API, or its local database. However, that should not affect its usage with the search functions.

ProductVariant.name: ProductVariant

ProductVariantOption.name: ProductVariantOption

Product.name: Product

ProductOption.name: ProductOption

MultipleResourceResult.name: MultipleResourceResult
MultipleResourceResult.description: The result of a fetch function where the input is multiple IDs. This object contains the resources that were found, as well as an array of IDs specifying which IDs, if any, did not correspond to a resource.

members.name: fetchedResources
members.description: The resources that were fetched using the IDs provided.

members.name: idsForResourcesNotFound
members.description: The IDs for which a resource was not found.

ProductSearchParams.name: ProductSearchParams

members.name: afterCursor
members.description: Specifies the page cursor. Items after this cursor will be returned.

members.name: first
members.description: Specifies the number of results to be returned in this page. The maximum number of items that will be returned is 50.

members.name: queryString
members.description: The search term to be used to search for POS products.

members.name: sortType
members.description: Specifies the order in which products should be sorted. When a `queryString` is provided, sortType will not have any effect, as the results will be returned in order by relevance to the `queryString`.

name: Scanner API
description: The Scanner API enables an extension to access scanner data and available scanning sources supported by the device.

ScannerApiContent.name: ScannerApiContent

members.name: scannerDataSubscribable
members.description: Creates a subscription to scan events Provides an initial value and a callback to subscribe to value changes. Currently supports only one subscription. You can utilize `makeStatefulSubscribable` on a `RemoteSubscribable` to implement multiple subscriptions. Using `makeStatefulSubscribable` or the corresponding hooks counts as a subscription.

members.name: scannerSourcesSubscribable
members.description: Creates a subscription to the scanning sources available on the POS device. Provides an initial value and a callback to subscribe to value changes. Currently supports only one subscription. You can utilize `makeStatefulSubscribable` on a `RemoteSubscribable` to implement multiple subscriptions. Using `makeStatefulSubscribable` or the corresponding hooks counts as a subscription.

ScannerSubscriptionResult.name: ScannerSubscriptionResult

members.name: data
members.description: The string data from the last scanner event received.

members.name: source
members.description: The scanning source from which the scan event came.

ScannerSource.name: ScannerSource
ScannerSource.description: The scanner source the POS device supports.

examples.description: Examples of receiving updates from the Scanner API

TS

codeblock.title: Receiving updates on available scanner sources

tabs.title: React
TS

examples.description: In this example, assuming a physical scanner is connected to the POS, any scans performed when ui extensions are in use will automatically add the product to the cart if the data exists on the shop.

tabs.title: React
TS

examples.description: There might be situations where a developer needs to conditionally render UI elements based on the available scanning sources of the device on which the extension is installed. For example, an extension could be designed for full-screen camera scanning, but a device like POS GO does not have a camera. In such cases, it would be necessary to avoid rendering the camera scanner component and instead create a UI that supports embedded scanning.

TS

members.name: getSessionToken

members.name: shopId
members.description: The shop ID associated with the shop currently logged into POS.

members.name: staffMemberId
members.description: The staff ID who is currently pinned into the POS. Note that this staff member ID may be different to the User ID, as the staff member who enters their PIN may be different to the User who logged onto POS.

members.name: userId
members.description: The user ID associated with the Shopify account currently authenticated on POS.

name: ActionItem
description: The `ActionItem` provides a tappable surface on the specified extension target as an entry point to an extension. Note that the text displayed on this `ActionItem` is dependent on the description of the extension.

ActionItemProps.name: ActionItemProps
ActionItemProps.description: Renders an `ActionItem` on action targets. Note that the text displayed on this `ActionItem` is dependent on the description of the extension.

members.name: onPress
members.description: The callback that is executed when the user taps the `ActionItem`.

name: Badge
description: Badges are used to inform merchants of the status of an item or action thats been taken.

BadgeProps.name: BadgeProps

members.name: status
members.description: A circle icon displaying the status of the badge.

members.name: text
members.description: The text displayed inside the badge.

members.name: variant
members.description: The appearance and function of the badge.

tabs.title: React
TS

subSections.title: Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent: - Badges should be positioned as close as possible to the item theyre related to.

subSections.title: Content guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
- Be concise. Use a single word to describe the status of an item. 
- Only use two or three words if you need to describe a complex state, for example "partially fulfilled".

 fulfilled
 order fulfilled

Statuses should ideally be written as adjectives:

 unpaid
 payment not received

name: Banner
description: A banner informs merchants about important changes or persistent conditions. Use if you need to communicate to merchants in a prominent way, without blocking other actions.

BannerProps.name: BannerProps

members.name: action
members.description: The text for the action button.

members.name: hideAction
members.description: Whether to hide the action button.

members.name: onPress
members.description: The callback function executed when the banner is pressed.

members.name: title
members.description: The title text displayed on the banner.

members.name: variant
members.description: The variant type of the banner.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visibility state of the banner.

tabs.title: React
TS

subSections.title: Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
- Use when needing to communicate to merchants in a way that is persistent but non-interruptive.
- Only one banner should be visible at a time.

name: Button
description: Buttons enable the merchant to initiate actions, like "add", "save", or "next".

ButtonProps.name: ButtonProps

members.name: isDisabled
members.description: Sets whether the `Button` can be tapped.

members.name: isLoading
members.description: Sets whether the `Button` is displaying an animated loading state.

members.name: onPress
members.description: The callback that is executed when the user taps the button.

members.name: title
members.description: The text set on the `Button`.

members.name: type

name: CameraScanner
description: The camera scanner uses the devices camera to scan and decode barcodes or QR codes. It displays a live feed with guidance markers for alignment and triggers actions within the app upon successful recognition.

CameraScannerBannerProps.name: CameraScannerBannerProps

members.name: title
members.description: The title of the banner.

members.name: variant
members.description: The appearance of the banner.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visibility state of the banner.

related.name: Scanner API
related.subtitle: See how to retrieve updates with the Scanner API.

codeblock.title: Camera scanner and data text example

tabs.title: React
TS

subSections.title: Best Practices
subSections.sectionContent:
- Utilize the error banner to display scanning errors or unrecognized barcodes at the top of the camera view screen.
- After a successful scan, dismiss the full-screen camera view and display a secondary screen showcasing the intended outcome.
- The camera scanner UI can be adjusted to display the camera view on part of the screen while dedicating the remaining portion to other components. This can be useful for tasks like inventory management.
- In situations where scanning should not be allowed within a specific section of your application, use an error banner to inform merchants that scanning is not permitted on that screen and offer alternative areas where the scanning function can be performed.
- Use the error banner at the top of the screen to denote errors while scanning or when encountering an unrecognized barcode.
- Upon successful scanning of an item, display a Toast component with a message such as "Item scanned" to indicate the outcome. Additionally, altering the screen contents can also be used to signal a successful scan.

subSections.title: Content guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
For banners: - Be concise. - Keep to 1 or 2 short sentences. - Be dismissible unless it contains critical information or an important step merchants need to take. Example: Scanning not permitted on this screen. Go to {Section} to scan items.
Dismiss (CTA)
Error. Barcode not recognized. Try scanning item again.
Dismiss (CTA)
Didnt work. For toasts: - Used for short messages to confirm an action. - Never go over 3 or 4 words. - Do not use for error messages. - Should be used for success messages. - Written in the pattern of noun + verb. Example: Item scanned.
Your item has been scanned and added to your inventory count!

name: Dialog
description: A dialog is a high-priority, intentionally disruptive message that requires action from the merchant before they can continue using POS.

DialogProps.name: DialogProps

members.name: actionText
members.description: The text displayed in the primary action button of the dialog.

members.name: content
members.description: The text displayed in the body of the dialog.

members.name: isVisible
members.description: Whether the dialog should be presented.

members.name: onAction
members.description: A callback that performs when the action is triggered.

members.name: onSecondaryAction
members.description: A callback that is executed when the secondary action is triggered.

members.name: secondaryActionText
members.description: The text displayed in the secondary action section of the dialog.

members.name: showSecondaryAction
members.description: Whether a secondary action displays.

members.name: title
members.description: The text displayed in the title of the dialog.

members.name: type
members.description: Determines the dialogs appearance and function.

tabs.title: React
TS

subSections.title: Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
- A dialog appears on top of the view the merchant is currently looking at.
- When a dialog appears, the merchant can only interact with the buttons in the dialog and nothing else in the view.
- A scrim is used to dim the UI in the background, using the surfaceBackground color set to 60% transparency.
- Dialogs always include at least one action, two actions at most.
- Buttons in dialogs work best when stacked to accommodate for longer translated content.
- When buttons are displayed side-by-side, the primary action is on the right. When buttons are stacked, the primary action is at the top.
- For buttons that initiate irreversible actions, the text should be displayed in "destructive" (red) state.

subSections.title: Content guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
For confirmation dialogs, the header should be formed as a question that re-emphasizes the action being taken. Don't write: "Are you sure?" Log out of Shopify POS?
Are you sure you want to log out of Shopify POS?
Youre about to log out of Shopify POS For confirmation dialogs, the primary button should clearly confirm the action while the secondary button should cancel the action with "Cancel": [Primary button] Log out
[Primary button] Yes For errors, the header should clearly communicate the problem rather than the solution (use the body and button to communicate the solution): [Header] Transaction declined
[Header] Retry transaction For informational dialogs where there's no action for the merchant to take but to acknowledge the message, the sole button should be "OK": [Button] OK
[Button] Understood
[Button] Dismiss

tabs.title: React
TS

subSections.title: Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
List items have a wide variety of use cases:

- To display and link to an object | Examples: an item in the cart, a customer in the customer list
- To display information | Examples: the payment breakdown in an order, staff contact information
- To display a menu item | Examples: an item on the first page of settings, an item in More actions
- To display a setting
- To display an action related to other items in the section
- To show a selectable option | Example: one filter option
- To display an external link

subSections.title: Content Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
Subtitles:

- Each subtitle should have a different piece of information. Don't use dashes to display more than one type of information on the same line.
- Subtitles should be shown in order of relevance.
- If you're showing the results of the form, the label should be the form field title and the subtitle should be the information the merchant entered.

members.description: The function to be called when the action button is pressed.

subSections.title: Validating a PIN Example
subSections.sectionContent:
This code defines a function onPinSubmit that simulates the validation of a Personal Identification Number (PIN). The function takes an array of numbers as input, representing the PIN entered by a user.

The function returns a Promise that resolves with a PinValidationResult, which can be either 'accept' or 'reject'. The Promise simulates an asynchronous operation using setTimeout with a delay of 1 second.

This code simulates an asynchronous operation using the setTimeout callback. The code checks if the entered PIN matches the sequence [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. If the entered PIN matches this sequence, the Promise resolves with 'accept'; otherwise, it resolves with 'reject'.

This function can be used to simulate PIN validation in a system where the correct PIN is [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6].

subSections.title: Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
*   Due to the nature of this component and the intended UX for this type of action, we recommend surfacing this in a full screen modal.

*   Please be advised that when utilizing the onSubmit callback, it is your responsibility to manage the navigation to the subsequent screen or dismissal of the modal. The component will only handle rejection of invalid PIN cases.

subSections.title: Content guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
When referring to a personal identification number, refer to it as a PIN, with all capital letters. Also when writing the PIN title or PinPadAction label: * Be concise * Never go over 4 words * Do not use punctuation * Start with a capital letter ### Title (Enter PIN) [PIN pad title] Enter PIN
[PIN pad title] Enter staff PIN
[PIN pad title] Create PIN
[PIN pad title] Please put in a PIN
[PIN pad title] Create a PIN ### PinPadAction (Generate random PIN, Clear) For PIN Pad actions, the action label should clearly communicate the action. [PIN pad action label] Generate random PIN
[PIN pad action label] Please create a new random PIN You can use just [verb], if it's obvious from the surrounding context what the [item] is: [PIN pad action label] Clear
[PIN pad action label] Clear PIN

related.name: ProductSearch API
related.subtitle: See how to use the ProductSearch API with a SearchBar to search for products.

tabs.title: React
TS

subSections.title: Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
- The global search bar should appear at the very top of a view, above the header. This is because it searches for things beyond the scope of that page.
- The inline search bar should appear at the top of a list, but under the header.
- The search bar should be sticky and remain at the top of the page when the merchant scrolls.
- When a merchant selects the search bar, the bar enters the focused state.
- When entering the focused state, the border turns blue and the search icon changes to a back arrow icon. Selecting the back arrow lets merchants return to the default state.
- If it's an inline search bar, entering focused state should also move the search bar to the top of the screen.
- When a merchant starts entering a search query, the bar enters the filled state.
- Selecting the **X** deletes the merchant's search query, but keeps them in the focused state so that they can immediately enter a new search query.

subSections.title: Content guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
For the placeholder text, use the pattern: "Search {items}"

 Search staff
 Search

description: Set of spacing constants to be used in the UI Extensions components library.

VerticalSpacing.ExtraSmall;
HorizontalSpacing.ExtraSmall;

tabs.title: TS
tabs.code:

name: Stack
description: A container for other components that allows them to be stacked horizontally or vertically. When building complex UIs, this will be your primary building block.

StackProps.name: StackProps

members.name: alignment
members.description: The alignment of the children along the cross axis.

members.name: direction
members.description: The direction of the stack.

members.name: flex
members.description: The flex value for the stack.

members.name: flexChildren
members.description: Whether the children should be stretched to fill the cross axis.

members.name: flexWrap
members.description: Wrap behavior for the children of the stack.

members.name: paddingHorizontal
members.description: The horizontal padding around the stack.

members.name: paddingVertical
members.description: The vertical padding around the stack.

members.name: spacing
members.description: The spacing between each child in the stack.

subSections.title: Examples
subSections.sectionContent: The following examples will demonstrate some, but not all of the abilities of the `Stack` component. In all the following examples we will be applying `horizontalPadding` of `ExtraExtraLarge`, since this is the default that we use on POS when we wrap our screens. For simplicity, these examples use the React version of the `Stack` component, but the same results will be achieved by using the same props with the regular JS library.

subSections.title: Horizontal Stack with default values
subSections.sectionContent: In this example, we specify `horizontal` for the `direction`. We don't specify the `flex`, which means it's 0 by default. However, `horizontal` stacks will always stretch to fill from the left to the right of the screen. As you can see, we have two small buttons occupying just the amount of space that they need, at the left side of the `Stack`. This is because `alignment` is set to `flex-end` by default.

tabs.title: React

subSections.title: Horizontal Stack with flexChildren
subSections.sectionContent: Similar to the example above, but this time we are specifying `flexChildren` to be `true`. This means that the two buttons will take up the max amount of space that they can within the `horizontal` stack.

tabs.title: React

subSections.title: Horizontal Stack with centered children
subSections.sectionContent: You can also center elements in your `horizontal` stack. For this, you can specify the `alignment` to be `center`. However, in this case you also want `flexChildren` to be `false` (which is the default), so that the children can take up the minimal amount of space that they need, and be centered.

tabs.title: React

subSections.title: Horizontal Stack with children at the end
subSections.sectionContent: To make the children be aligned to the end of your `horizontal` container, you just need to specify `alignment` to be `flex-end`. Note that in the first example, the children were at the start of the container. This is because the default value is `flex-start`.

codeblock.title: Horizontal Stack with children at the end

tabs.title: React

subSections.title: Vertical Stack
subSections.sectionContent: You can specify your `Stack` to layout its children vertically by setting `direction` to `vertical`.

tabs.title: React

subSections.title: Vertical Stack with centered children
subSections.sectionContent: You can center your stack's children along the `vertical` axis by setting the `alignment` to `center`. However, because `vertical` stacks only take up the minimal amount of `vertical` space required when `flex` is set to `0` (which is by default), you will need to set `flex` to `1`

tabs.title: React

subSections.title: Vertical Stack with children at the bottom
subSections.sectionContent: You can set your children to the bottom of your `vertical` stack by setting `alignment` to `flex-end`. As explained in the previous example, you also need to set `flex` to `1`, since the default is `0`, which will make your container only take up the minimum amount of space it needs.

codeblock.title: Vertical Stack with children at the bottom

tabs.title: React

subSections.title: Nested Stack
subSections.sectionContent:
Now that we've run through a few examples of what a `Stack` can do, let's move on to something more complex. You can nest multiple Stacks of different configurations to achieve a more complex UI. In this example, we will create a row that displays several labels and an icon. This will mimic some of the basic rows that you can find across different POS screens.

Let's put the `Selectable` aside for now; we'll get to that later. If you look at the first `Stack`, this is our parent `Stack`. We've set its `direction` to `horizontal` and its `alignment` to `space-between`. Then, we've added some vertical and horizontal padding (as highlighted in the screenshot).

As you can see, there are two child Stacks. Because the parent `Stack` is set to `space-between`, these two child Stacks are spread to each end of the parent horizontal `Stack`. Both of these child Stacks occupy the amount of space they need, but not more.

The first child `Stack` is a simple vertical `Stack` that stacks the two left labels. It specifies the `spacing` to be `0.5` (the default is `1`, and this was a bit too much).

The second child `Stack` has another nested `Stack`. Let's discuss the nested `Stack` first. This is a horizontal `Stack` that lays out a text label and an icon horizontally. We then apply a bit of padding. That horizontal `Stack` is wrapped in a vertical `Stack`. The reason for this is to align the horizontal `Stack` on the center of the vertical axis, giving it a nicer appearance. Without it, the horizontal `Stack` would be located at the same height as the "Hello world!" `Text` on the left side of our row. But by specifying a `flex` of `1`, we are telling the vertical `Stack` to take as much vertical space as it can within its parent container. And then we specify an alignment of center, which lays out its child horizontal `Stack` on the center of its vertical axis.

Finally, we can return to the `Selectable`. You'll notice that we've wrapped the entire `Stack` in a `Selectable`. This makes the entire `Stack` within the `Selectable` become a tappable surface, with an `onPress` handler, which is part of the `Selectable` component. It also gives a nice highlight effect when you tap, as you can see in the screenshot.

name: TextArea
description: Use a text input to allow merchants to input or modify multiline text.

definitions.title: TextArea
definitions.description: A text field which supports multiple lines.

TextAreaProps.name: TextAreaProps

members.name: action
members.description: A button under the text field to provide extra functionality.

members.name: disabled
members.description: Whether the field can be modified.

members.name: error
members.description: Indicates an error to the user. The field is given specific stylistic treatment to communicate problems that have to be resolved immediately.

members.name: helpText
members.description: The label under the text field which provides guidance or instructions that assist users.

members.name: label
members.description: The content to use as the field label.

members.name: maxLength
members.description: The maximum number of characters allowed in the input field.

members.name: onBlur
members.description: The callback when focus is removed.

members.name: onChange
members.description: The callback when the user has finished editing a field.

members.name: onFocus
members.description: The callback when input is focused.

members.name: onInput
members.description: Callback when the user makes any changes in the field. As noted in the documentation for `onChange`, you **must not** use this to update `value`  use the `onChange` callback for that purpose. Use the `onInput` prop when you need to do something as soon as the user makes a change, like clearing validation errors that apply to the field as soon as the user begins making the necessary adjustments.

members.name: placeholder
members.description: A short hint that describes the expected value of the field.

members.name: required
members.description: Whether the field needs a value.

members.name: rows
members.description: The initial number of lines to be displayed. Maximum of 8 lines.

members.name: value
members.description: The current value for the field. Defaults to now. You should update this value in response to the `onChange` callback.

InputAction.name: InputAction

members.name: disabled
members.description: Whether the button can be pressed.

members.name: label
members.description: The text displayed in the button.

members.name: onPress
members.description: A callback to be performed.

tabs.title: React
TS

subSections.title: Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
- When a merchant opens a new form, the first text field should be in a focused state.
- If the merchant is actively focused in a text field, then the keyboard should come up and the label should move to the top of the field.
- If focus goes away from the text field, then the keyboard should hide.
- Text fields always take up the full screen width.
- Text fields dont change height. If text entered is longer than the width of the text field, then the oldest text on the left should be hidden to make room.
- When it makes sense, provide autocomplete options (for example, entering an address).

subSections.title: Content Guidelines
subSections.sectionContent:
- If a text field is required, then it should indicate `Required`.
- Label titles should be brief and written in sentence case.
- Use the same terms for similar label titles throughout the app.

name: Tile
description: Tiles are customizable buttons that allow staff to complete actions quickly. Think of them as shortcuts--adding a 10% discount to an order, for example. Tiles provide contextual information and let merchants quickly access workflows, actions, and information from the smart grid and the top of detail pages. Theyre dynamic and can change based on surrounding context, such as whats in the cart.

TileProps.name: TileProps

members.name: badgeValue
members.description: The number value displayed in the top right corner of the tile.

members.name: destructive
members.description: Sets whether or not the tile is in a red destructive appearance.

members.name: enabled
members.description: Sets whether or not the tile can be tapped.

members.name: onPress
members.description: The callback that is executed when the tile is tapped.

members.name: subtitle
members.description: The text set on the secondary label of the tile.

members.name: title
members.description: The text set on the main label of the tile.

members.description: (Android only) Whether the clock displays in 24 hour time instead of 12 hour time.

members.name: label
members.description: The content to use as the field label.

members.name: onBlur
members.description: The callback when focus is removed.

TimeFieldProps.value:
export interface TimeFieldProps
  extends Pick<
    InputProps,
    | 'value'
    | 'error'
    | 'label'
    | 'disabled'
    | 'onFocus'
    | 'onBlur'
    | 'onChange'
    | 'action'
    | 'helpText'
  > {
  /**
   * (Android only) Whether the clock displays in 24 hour time instead of 12 hour time.
   * @defaultValue false
   */
  is24Hour?: boolean;
}

members.name: inputMode
members.description: Whether to display the picker in inline (clock) mode or spinner mode. iOS only supports 'spinner'.

members.name: is24Hour
members.description: (Android only) Whether the clock displays in 24 hour time instead of 12 hour time.

members.name: onChange
members.description: A callback for changes.

members.name: selected
members.description: The selected time.

members.name: visibleState
members.description: Controls the visible state, and a callback to set the visible state as false when the dialog closes.
